content.description: The problem is both classic and contrived. Start on the great jug hold slightly above head height, pull-up and mantle using just one arm to execute both the pull-up and the mantle. After I had straight armed the mantle out, I attempted to get my foot of the same jug hold that my hand was on,.. it was proving awkward balance wise, so I lightly stabilized my body using my other arm and hand on top of the boulder. I had envisioned the problem as using entirely one arm,.. but, I came up short,.. Still, by far the singular most powerful move that I have ever done. I used my left arm for the move.
content.protection: I did the problem without a pad(s), however the year was late Winter of 1982.
content.location: Located in the small boulder field at the base of the South Face of Stone Mountain, as I recall, basically below Pandora's Way. The boulder is comprised of a South facing blunt arete the is slightly overhang with a great hold slightly above head height.

content.description: Can either climb the crack in the middle for an easy hike up, or use the corner on the left for some harder slapping.
content.protection: Pads if you want, not a very sketchy landing.
content.location: Trailside boulder next to kiosk when you first walk up.

content.description: Kind of a head game when you get up there.
content.location: Walk behind the kiosk and follow the runoff path down the hilll towards the highball. Pass highball on left and look left when you turn the corner. It's the huge slab, hard to miss.

content.description:
Sit start on small holds with a right foot.  Fire up to the left to a jug.  Begin to work the jugs and crimps until topping out.  Do not use the adjacent face, stay on the arete.

If anyone knows FA name or correct route name please let me know.  These are on here just as a guide to show climbers what Stone has to offer.
content.location: When approaching the South Face of Stone Mountain the problem is in the boulder field on the right (East).  This problem is straight down the hill from the start for U-Slot (50 yards)  Look for boulder with a prominent arete and blank face.  Walk off from the top.

content.description:
Begin on two good side pulls on the left.  Use balance to walk your feet up the slabby face.  Good hold on the left near the top will give way to a good right hold.  Top out via juggy top.  The arete on the left is off.

If anyone knows FA name or correct route name please let me know.  These are on here just as a guide to show climbers what Stone has to offer.
content.location: When approaching the South Face of Stone Mountain the problem is in the boulder field on the right (East).  Problem is on a slabby boulder around 100 yards off of the trail.  Walk off the back of the boulder

content.description: Start with both hands on good left double side pull with left foot on nib and right smeared. Next hold is a right big crimp which you match with left hand, followed by a high right heel over top. Bump up right hand to top and then bring left foot back to start hold to walk up left hand to top and top out.
content.location: Go past the kiosk to the right about 100 meters to where the giant flat top rock is. It is directly underneath the giant flattop towards the field. About 75 feet from Firing Squad route.
